VOL. XXV. No. 12

FOOTBALL SCHEDULE FOR
NEXT YEAR ANNOUNCED
Nine Games to Be Played—Washington and Lee Met on Thanksgiving—No Game With Maryland.

FOOTBALL SCHEDULE.
1921.
October 1—Mt. St. Mary's.
October 8—Delaware.
October 15—Dickinson.
October 22—Virginia.
October 29—Western Maryland.
November 5—Haverford.
November 12—Swarthmore or Columbia.
November 19—St. John's.
November 24— Washington and
Lee.
In arranging the football schedule for next year, the football authorities have been guided by the
desire to allow the team to work
up gradually to the most important games of the season so as
to have the men in the best possible condition at that time. Accordingly, the first three games on
the list are with Mt. St. Mary's,
Delaware and Dickinson, teams
Which are generally not above the
average in ability, although Mt.
St. Mary's shows signs of developing a fast squad and may give
Hopkins trouble.
The game with Virginia follows.
This contest is now arranged for
Charlottesville, although efforts
are being made to transfer it to
Baltimore because of the large
crowd it would attract in this
city. Western Maryland, coming
after the Southerners, will have
to improve a good deal to beat
Hopkins, while Haverford, the following week, is sure to furnish a
closely contested game. The Pennsylvanians,- it will be remembered,
were defeated by the Black and
Blue this fall for the first time in
many years.
The next Saturday, November
12, Swarthmore will be met at
Homewood or Columbia in New
York. A game with the "Little
Quakers," a traditional opponent
of Hopkins, would seem more desirable from the point of view of
interest than a journey to another
city. St. John's will come to Baltimore on November 19, and, as
usual, can be relied upon to play
a fighting game. Washington and
Lee, a newcomer to Hopkins
schedules, will visit Homewood on
Turkey Day.
The break with University of
Maryland thus appears to be complete. The trouble which began
With the playing of Roy Mackert
was increased by Maryland's desire for_ a greater share of the gate
receipts, and finally has led to the
abandonment of the traditional

BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 21, 1920

APPRECIATION
Every undergraduate student in the University is asked to
contribute at least twenty-five cents today toward a fund to
present Barney O'Rourke with a gold watch as a mark of appreciation for his work with the football. squad this fall. Mr.
O'Rourke came down to Baltimore, receiving only his expenses,
leaving Philadelphia, where he is a partner in the contracting
firm of O'Rourke Brothers & Co., and developed the best line
that has ever played for Hopkins. While playing for Cornell
several years ago O'Rourke, with Van Orman, was named by
Walter Camp as a member of the All-American Football Team.
The collection box for the money will be placed near the
"Barn" at 12.30 o'clock today and donations will be received until
6 o'Elock. The committee in charge of the collection of the money
and purchase of the watch is composed of Edmund S. Wood,
captain of the 1920 football team; Jacob E. Miller, Bartus Trew
and Milton Goldstein. Eighty-five dollars has already been
donated and the committee needs about fifty dollars more.

PREPARATION BEGINS FOR
WINTER TRACK -

R. 0. T. C. OFFICERS TO BE
• RERATED

Board Track Laid Down—Outdoor
Work Started—Men Needed
For Field Events.

Reorganization in January—Unit to
March in Inaugural
Parade.

Informal track practice in
preparation for the big indoor
meets began Thursday on the 220yard board track. All men now on
the track roll are expected to report for this conditioning practice; and it is hoped that a large
number of new men will show up
before the formal organization is
called for.
The course of training to be followed combines the best features
of indoor and outdoor work. A
good springy well-banked track
such as is used for the actual
meets has been laid on Straus
Field; in this way all the advan
tages of indoor training are secured without forcing the abandonment of the benefits derived
from practice in the open quicker
hardening, fresh air and a more
stimulating temperature than is
found indoors. This is the method
of training now used at many of
the Northern colleges.
Although the prospects in the
runs are very bright, Hopkins'
usual weakness in the field events
is thisirear more pronounced than
ever.'Pole vaulters, high jumpers,
broad jumpers and weight men
are urgently needed. Any man
with any experience or any reason
to suspect he may develop some
talent along these lines is requested to report to Capt. "Reds"
Mullikin any day at the field at
5 o'clock.
The formal organization meeting will be held immediately following the return after the New
Year. Definite arrangements will
be announced at this meeting.
Meanwhile get out and get into
condition.

The rerating of officers in the R.
O. T. C. battalion will be carried
out between January 3 and March
4, at which latter date the unit
will march in President-elect
Harding's inaugural parade in
Washington. This rerating will
mean a complete reorganization of
the military unit, which will be
carried on by Major Garey, Captain McMurray and Student
Major Chisolm.
As at present Sophomores will
supply the non-commissioned officer positions Juniors will have
the rank of lieutenants and
Seniors the higher ranks. The
decisions for promotion and demotion will be based on the practical work of the students.
FRATERNITIES TO ENTERTAIN
VISITING PLAYERS.

At a regular meeting of the
Interfraternity Board it. was decided that each Fraternity on the
campus should house one or two
men who come here with basketball teams of other colleges. This
will help the Athletic Association
in furnishing their guarantee and
will also give a better impression
of Hopkins life than would be obtained if the visitors were put up
at hotels.
MUSICAL CLUB TO GIVE CONCERT AT ANNAPOLIS.

The Musical Club has arranged
to give a concert in the Town Hall
at Annapolis on January 6. This
is the first of a number of out-oftown concerts, and the Club deserves much credit for undertaking so ambitious a program. The
organization has already called
forth much praise for its unusual
high calibre, and it %cannot help
but add to its prestige if properly
supported.

PRICE 10 CENTS

BASEBALL SCHEDULE PRACTICALLY COMPLETED
Hopkins to Have Well-Balanced
Schedule—Only Two Games to
be Played Away From Home.
Trip to Virginia During
Easter Vacation.

Work is now well advanced on
the 1921 baseball schedule, which
promises to be one of the most
successful ever arranged. A large
majority of the games will be with
well-known colleges, but colleges
that are in Hopkins' class, so that
well-fought, closely, contested encounters are assured. Manager
Biemiller is also planning to play
all but two or three games at
Homewood.
Among the strongest nines on
the schedule• are the University
of Virginia, Stevens, Pennsylvania, Swarthmore and Washington College. Nearly all the Virginia institutions will be met, including V. M. I., whose football
team was the Southern sensation
of the year. V. P. I. has not yet
agreed to play Hopkins, although
a game will probably be arranged.
Four State teams will come to
Homewood.
The mistake which' was made
last year of scheduling a number
of contests on consecutive days
has not been repeated. Such an
arrangement proved far too great
a strain on the team, and on the
pitchers especially. This year's
plan offers ample time for rest
between games.
Battery practice will be started
about the middle of February at
the Fifth Regiment Armory.
Bobby Owings and Bill Wood are
the only regular battery men remaining at the University, so that
there is at present a great opportunity for new men. In fact, new
candidates for all positions will
have a fine chance of making the
squad, since few veterans will
turn out for the spring practice.
"Herb" Armstrong will again
coach the nine. Last year he was
most popular with the men and
proved to be an excellent coach;
this year he may be depended
upon to develop a well-balanced
squad.
A Freshman team will also be
organized and a complete schedule
arranged.
The tentative Varsity schedule
is as follows:
March 25—University of Richmond (away).
March 26—University of Virginia (away).
March 28—Stevens.
March 31—University of Pennsylvania.
April 2—Haverford (pending).
April 9—Still open.

RIFLE CLUB TO ORGANIZE
THURSDAY
Meeting

After

Johns Hopkins Press

Assembly — Many

Already Signed Up.

The University's latest activity
will come into formal being next
Thursday immediately after the
assembly, when the organization
meeting of the Johns Hopkins
Rifle Club will be held. Already
55 men of the University have
signed up for membership in the
club, thus securing the rating of
charter members. This list will
remain open until noon on Thursday so that as many as possible
may avail themselves of the opportunity to be known as among
the club's founders. Soon after
its organization the shooters will
begin practicing for entering into
competition with other universities.
The Intercollegiate Rifle Association classes the various member clubs according to the length
of time that they have been in existence as well as according to
their ability to shoot. For this
reason the Johns Hopkins Club
will be placed in a low class, although in ability it may come to
be in a very high one.
track; although the American
students go out for all sports they
excel only in track, for the other
games are played according to
English rules.
It is quite interesting to note
that Hopkins has sent the majority of men from the State of Maryland to Oxford. Most of these men
were residents of Maryland attending school here, but a man
from any State going to school in
another State may apply for the
scholarship in either State.
Princeton has sent three times as
many men to Oxford on Rhodes
scholarships as any other college
in the United States.
Along with the lecture a number of lantern slides were shown
which proved instructive and interesting.
Time alone can tell whether the
plan of Cecil Rhodes will prove
successful or not. The scholarships are not political missionary
enterprises; a man is given an opportunity to study in a foreign
college in a foreign country where
the point of view differs entirely
from that to which he has been accustomed and the value of this
alone cannot be estimated in dollars and cents.

COACH LAMBORN DRILLS
BASKETEERS ON
TEAMWORK
No Individual Playing This Year.
Squad Unity to be Stressed. First
Game December 30.

The basketball team is rapidly
being whipped into first-class
shape under the able coaching of
Coach Lamborn. It was found impracticable to use the Armory this
week, so practice has been held
daily at Friends' School, where
due to the limited space only
about twenty men can work out.
Great attention is being paid to
the fundamentals of the game, a
large part of each afternoon being
devoted to the development of
passing, blocking and team work
Coach Lamborn is
in general.
laying the utmost stress on the
latter, for he believes that without
it no team can accomplish much.
This was well exemplified in the
team of last year, composed of five
individual stars who put up some
wonderful games, but who always
played as five men shooting for
the same basket, never as a team.
This year the long shots which
were so prominent last year are
to be done away with, and though
there are no men of the brilliancy
of Scheurich or Weinert, yet there
is ample material for a good team.
Under Coach Lamborn men such
as Capt. "Bill" Wood, Cashell,
Kennedy, Bauernschmidt, Owings,
Barrett, Jolson and Jefferson
can be moulded into a fast, unified team which should do very
well with the splendid schedule
Manager Reed has provided. The
first game will be played at the
Armory on December 30 with
Union. The rest of the schedule
is as follows:
January 7—Swarthmore.
January 14—Rutgers.
January 21—Open.
January 28—George Washington (away).
February 4—Washington and
Lee.
February 11—Open.
February 17—Princeton.

The Swimming Team commenced practice in earnest last
Wednesday afternoon in the B. A.
C. tank. Coach Henry was on
hand and put the men through
their customary paces, holding the
watch on some who have been
working out regularly for some
time. This early in the season it
is impossible to make any definite
predictions as to the men who are
slated to represent the University
during the year, but it seems that
the team should be as strong ag
formerly in all departments except
the "plunge for distance, as there
are but two candidates, neither of
whom are veterans, out for this
event.
In addition to Captain Rowland, one of the mainstays of the
team, the following men have
shown up exceptionally well:
Hall, Coady, Reins, Call, Johnston, Gould, Buhrer, Aguado,
Hambleton, Mellen and Keyes.
Manager Gould has completed
a well-balanced schedule, which,
however, calls for the majority of
meets taking place out of town,
leaving Hopkins rooters but two
chances to see their team in action. The schedule follows:
January 7—C. C. N. Y. at New
York.
January 8—Columbia at New
York.
January 15—Navy at Annapolis.
January 21—Swarthmore at
home.
February 18—Lehigh at South
Bethlehem.
February 25—Rutgers at home.
March 5—Interc011egiate Championships at New Brunswick
(Rutgers).

FRESHMAN-SOPHOMORE DEBATE SCHEDULED FOR
JANUARY 14
Question Same as Varsity Will Discuss
In Triangular Contest. Undergraduate Orchestra to
Furnish Music.

The Freshman-Sophomore debate will be held in the C. E. Hall
Friday night, January 14. The subject for debate will be on the same
general question as that which
will be discussed by the Varsity
team in the Triangular Debates
with North Carolina and Washington and Lee. The proposition
has been amended to read, "Resolved, That all immigration, save
of children, parents, or husband
or wife of people now resident in
the United States, be stopped for
a period of ten years." This reading of the proposition gives the op.
posing teams no room for • quibbling and presents a real bone of
contention.
The teams picked to represent
the., two classes are unusually
good. The Sophomores are able
to present intact the team which
was easily victorious in last year's
Freshman-Sophomore struggle. P.
C. Williams, A. P. Emmart and
Diamond will debate with Herman for alternate. For the Freshman Barnhart, Mount and Terlitzky will mount the stump, with
Eisenberg in reserve. All of these
men have had prep school experience and Mount was one of the
shining lights down in Montgomery County.
The committee on arrangements
consists of B. S. Cannon, '22; L.
B. Fenneman,'23, and Devers,'24.
The Undergraduate Orchestra
will furnish music.

THE NEWS LETTER'S
MAILBAG
A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, But Shoulder the Responsibility.
All letters intended for publication
must be concise.
No attention will be paid to anonymous letters, but- names signed as an
evidence of good faith will not be printed
if request is made that they be omitted.
The publication of a letter is not to be
taken as an indorsement of its views by
THE NEWS-LETTER, which invites the
freest discussion of matters of general
interest.

To Editor of The News-Letter:
Dear Sir—I believe this is an
Opportune time to bring up a topic
which is of especial interest to fellows from out of town who are attending Hopkins. I refer to the
short vacations which the University extends at Christmas and
Easter. I think I speak for many
others beside myself when I voice
dissatisfaction with the present
arrangement. I know there are
many. students who live far from
Baltimore who are unable to make
the trip home in so short a time
and who feel that the expense is
not warranted for so short a vacation. Other universities are giving two and one-half weeks for
Christmas recess, thus enabling
nearly all their students to enjoy
their Christmas around the family
hearth. I think it is a crying
shame that the University officials
do not give a little more consideration to the men who come from
the four corners of the country to
extend the name and prestige of
their loved Alma Mater.
The Easter recess extends from
Thursday to Thursday. Why
could this not be extended to the
following Monday? If Hopkins is
ever going to draw men outside
of Baltimore it has got to show
more consideration for them and
enable them to be with their families for a time more nearly approaching that extended by other
institutions. I am writing this
not so much in the spirit of criticism as of fair play. Hopkins is
in Baltimore, but not all for Baltimore.
ROBERT K. GUGGENHEIMER.

J. H. U. PRODUCES MANY
EMINENT MEN
Its Small Student-Body
Stands Supreme in Field of
Geology.

With

It

(From The Baltimore News, December 16.)
Hopkins, as a developer of
scientific students, has prided
itself primarily, not so much in
the quantity of its university influx as in the quality of its university output. Being a local institution, few Baltimoreans stop
to consider its position as compared with other,great American
universities, consequently, when
one undertakes to search out comparative statistics, it is often necessary to seek for sources of information beyond the borders of
Maryland.
Interesting material in this respect has been provided by
Charles Keyes, an eminent scien
tist of the present day, who, after
a canvass of the "starred" men
from 30 leading universities of the
country, found that while Hopkins
ranked thirtieth so far as attendance was concerned,. among a
thousand American men who have
become great during their genera
tion, and who have maintained
themselves in the advance thought
of the nation, Hopkins turned out
no less than 240. In other words,
one-fourth of the master-minsls of
American science have been produced by the Baltimore mainspring of scientific training.
It seems rather remarkable in
a way that classes carrying the
least attendance are often more
fruitful in the production of lead-

George Otis Shilth, head of the
United States Geological Survey
at Washington and a geologist of
national repute, is one of many
Hopkins men connected with the
survey, while Timothy Stanton, L.
W. Stevenson and C. Wyth Cook
are others who claim the local institution as their alma mater.
In this particular field, however, not more than four or five
men are turned out each year at
Homewood, while the general en
rollment for the course shows an
average of only 100 members.
Many men taking up this study
do so merely to fulfill requirements of the curriculum, and the
percentage of those that follow
the subject for more than a year
is small.
Enrollments this year fail to
show any material increase in
geological work. While the class •
of '23 is the largest at the University few Sophomores have been
able to enter the course as yet.
Dr. C. K. Swartz, head of the department, has advanced requirements as far as possible in order
to discourage the entrance of the
two lower divisions of classmen,
as facilities for handling large
numbers are very limited.
Yet conditions on the whole
have not varied greatly. While
admitting but a comparatively
small number each year, Hopkins
has continued to maintain its enviable record, and its production
of eminent men is a sufficient criterion of its success in this regard.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, DECEMBER 21, 1920

DRAMATIC CLUB TO START
WORK ON MAJOR PRODUCTION

• •• ••••• II
• • II •• II • II •

that means
the best
in clothes

"Captain Jenks of the Horse Marine"
Chosen—Actors and Property
Men Wanted.

The Dramatic Club has definitely decided on the play to be
given for its big production and
will start rehearsals Tuesday, December 22. The Club has already
given several one-act plays in their
studio in the "Barn" which have
been very successful, and in selecting a play for its major production has gotten one which will
appeal to the Hopkins man.
After very careful consideration
on the part of the Club it has been
decided to present "Captain Jenks
of the Horse Marine," by Clyde
Fitch, a comedy in three acts. The
Club will again have the services
of Miss Clementine Walter as director. Miss Walter has coached
the Club in all its major productions since its foundation
three years ago and is largely responsible for the high standing
which it holds.
The Club makes, a special appeal for men who will take female
parts in the play and also for scenery painters and electricians. One
need have no experience in properties to try out for that end.
There are many openings for both
cast and business end which will
be filled by the men who show
themselves most capable and inter
ested.
In order to put this play on,
which will cost at least $1000, it
is imperative that the Club have
the backing of the entire studentbody—every man of it—and their
friends. The rehearsals and tryouts will begin on Tuesday, December 22, from 1 to 6 o'clock, in
the Club studio. Rehearsals will
be held during Christmas week
but will be called off the two weeks
preceding examinations.

FOOTBALL SCHEDULE FOR
NEXT YEAR ANNOUNCED
Nine Games to Be Played—Washington and Lee Met on Thanksgiving—No Game With Maryland.

FOOTBALL SCHEDULE.
1921.
October 1—Mt. St. Mary's.
October 8—Delaware.
October 15—Dickinson.
October 22—Virginia.
October 29—Western Maryland.
November 5—Haverford.
November 12—Swarthmore or Columbia.
November 19—St. John's.
November 24— Washington and
Lee.
In arranging the football schedule for next year, the football authorities have been guided by the
desire to allow the team to work
up gradually to the most important games of the season so as
to have the men in the best possible condition at that time. Accordingly, the first three games on
the list are with Mt. St. Mary's,
Delaware and Dickinson, teams
Which are generally not above the
average in ability, although Mt.
St. Mary's shows signs of developing a fast squad and may give
Hopkins trouble.
The game with Virginia follows.
This contest is now arranged for
Charlottesville, although efforts
are being made to transfer it to
Baltimore because of the large
crowd it would attract in this
city. Western Maryland, coming
after the Southerners, will have
to improve a good deal to beat
Hopkins, while Haverford, the following week, is sure to furnish a
closely contested game. The Pennsylvanians,- it will be remembered,
were defeated by the Black and
Blue this fall for the first time in
many years.
The next Saturday, November
12, Swarthmore will be met at
Homewood or Columbia in New
York. A game with the "Little
Quakers," a traditional opponent
of Hopkins, would seem more desirable from the point of view of
interest than a journey to another
city. St. John's will come to Baltimore on November 19, and, as
usual, can be relied upon to play
a fighting game. Washington and
Lee, a newcomer to Hopkins
schedules, will visit Homewood on
Turkey Day.
The break with University of
Maryland thus appears to be complete. The trouble which began
With the playing of Roy Mackert
was increased by Maryland's desire for_ a greater share of the gate
receipts, and finally has led to the
abandonment of the traditional

BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 21, 1920

APPRECIATION
Every undergraduate student in the University is asked to
contribute at least twenty-five cents today toward a fund to
present Barney O'Rourke with a gold watch as a mark of appreciation for his work with the football. squad this fall. Mr.
O'Rourke came down to Baltimore, receiving only his expenses,
leaving Philadelphia, where he is a partner in the contracting
firm of O'Rourke Brothers & Co., and developed the best line
that has ever played for Hopkins. While playing for Cornell
several years ago O'Rourke, with Van Orman, was named by
Walter Camp as a member of the All-American Football Team.
The collection box for the money will be placed near the
"Barn" at 12.30 o'clock today and donations will be received until
6 o'Elock. The committee in charge of the collection of the money
and purchase of the watch is composed of Edmund S. Wood,
captain of the 1920 football team; Jacob E. Miller, Bartus Trew
and Milton Goldstein. Eighty-five dollars has already been
donated and the committee needs about fifty dollars more.

PREPARATION BEGINS FOR
WINTER TRACK -

R. 0. T. C. OFFICERS TO BE
• RERATED

Board Track Laid Down—Outdoor
Work Started—Men Needed
For Field Events.

Reorganization in January—Unit to
March in Inaugural
Parade.

Informal track practice in
preparation for the big indoor
meets began Thursday on the 220yard board track. All men now on
the track roll are expected to report for this conditioning practice; and it is hoped that a large
number of new men will show up
before the formal organization is
called for.
The course of training to be followed combines the best features
of indoor and outdoor work. A
good springy well-banked track
such as is used for the actual
meets has been laid on Straus
Field; in this way all the advan
tages of indoor training are secured without forcing the abandonment of the benefits derived
from practice in the open quicker
hardening, fresh air and a more
stimulating temperature than is
found indoors. This is the method
of training now used at many of
the Northern colleges.
Although the prospects in the
runs are very bright, Hopkins'
usual weakness in the field events
is thisirear more pronounced than
ever.'Pole vaulters, high jumpers,
broad jumpers and weight men
are urgently needed. Any man
with any experience or any reason
to suspect he may develop some
talent along these lines is requested to report to Capt. "Reds"
Mullikin any day at the field at
5 o'clock.
The formal organization meeting will be held immediately following the return after the New
Year. Definite arrangements will
be announced at this meeting.
Meanwhile get out and get into
condition.

The rerating of officers in the R.
O. T. C. battalion will be carried
out between January 3 and March
4, at which latter date the unit
will march in President-elect
Harding's inaugural parade in
Washington. This rerating will
mean a complete reorganization of
the military unit, which will be
carried on by Major Garey, Captain McMurray and Student
Major Chisolm.
As at present Sophomores will
supply the non-commissioned officer positions Juniors will have
the rank of lieutenants and
Seniors the higher ranks. The
decisions for promotion and demotion will be based on the practical work of the students.
FRATERNITIES TO ENTERTAIN
VISITING PLAYERS.

At a regular meeting of the
Interfraternity Board it. was decided that each Fraternity on the
campus should house one or two
men who come here with basketball teams of other colleges. This
will help the Athletic Association
in furnishing their guarantee and
will also give a better impression
of Hopkins life than would be obtained if the visitors were put up
at hotels.
MUSICAL CLUB TO GIVE CONCERT AT ANNAPOLIS.

The Musical Club has arranged
to give a concert in the Town Hall
at Annapolis on January 6. This
is the first of a number of out-oftown concerts, and the Club deserves much credit for undertaking so ambitious a program. The
organization has already called
forth much praise for its unusual
high calibre, and it %cannot help
but add to its prestige if properly
supported.

PRICE 10 CENTS

BASEBALL SCHEDULE PRACTICALLY COMPLETED
Hopkins to Have Well-Balanced
Schedule—Only Two Games to
be Played Away From Home.
Trip to Virginia During
Easter Vacation.

Work is now well advanced on
the 1921 baseball schedule, which
promises to be one of the most
successful ever arranged. A large
majority of the games will be with
well-known colleges, but colleges
that are in Hopkins' class, so that
well-fought, closely, contested encounters are assured. Manager
Biemiller is also planning to play
all but two or three games at
Homewood.
Among the strongest nines on
the schedule• are the University
of Virginia, Stevens, Pennsylvania, Swarthmore and Washington College. Nearly all the Virginia institutions will be met, including V. M. I., whose football
team was the Southern sensation
of the year. V. P. I. has not yet
agreed to play Hopkins, although
a game will probably be arranged.
Four State teams will come to
Homewood.
The mistake which' was made
last year of scheduling a number
of contests on consecutive days
has not been repeated. Such an
arrangement proved far too great
a strain on the team, and on the
pitchers especially. This year's
plan offers ample time for rest
between games.
Battery practice will be started
about the middle of February at
the Fifth Regiment Armory.
Bobby Owings and Bill Wood are
the only regular battery men remaining at the University, so that
there is at present a great opportunity for new men. In fact, new
candidates for all positions will
have a fine chance of making the
squad, since few veterans will
turn out for the spring practice.
"Herb" Armstrong will again
coach the nine. Last year he was
most popular with the men and
proved to be an excellent coach;
this year he may be depended
upon to develop a well-balanced
squad.
A Freshman team will also be
organized and a complete schedule
arranged.
The tentative Varsity schedule
is as follows:
March 25—University of Richmond (away).
March 26—University of Virginia (away).
March 28—Stevens.
March 31—University of Pennsylvania.
April 2—Haverford (pending).
April 9—Still open.

RIFLE CLUB TO ORGANIZE
THURSDAY
Meeting

After

Johns Hopkins Press

Assembly — Many

Already Signed Up.

The University's latest activity
will come into formal being next
Thursday immediately after the
assembly, when the organization
meeting of the Johns Hopkins
Rifle Club will be held. Already
55 men of the University have
signed up for membership in the
club, thus securing the rating of
charter members. This list will
remain open until noon on Thursday so that as many as possible
may avail themselves of the opportunity to be known as among
the club's founders. Soon after
its organization the shooters will
begin practicing for entering into
competition with other universities.
The Intercollegiate Rifle Association classes the various member clubs according to the length
of time that they have been in existence as well as according to
their ability to shoot. For this
reason the Johns Hopkins Club
will be placed in a low class, although in ability it may come to
be in a very high one.
track; although the American
students go out for all sports they
excel only in track, for the other
games are played according to
English rules.
It is quite interesting to note
that Hopkins has sent the majority of men from the State of Maryland to Oxford. Most of these men
were residents of Maryland attending school here, but a man
from any State going to school in
another State may apply for the
scholarship in either State.
Princeton has sent three times as
many men to Oxford on Rhodes
scholarships as any other college
in the United States.
Along with the lecture a number of lantern slides were shown
which proved instructive and interesting.
Time alone can tell whether the
plan of Cecil Rhodes will prove
successful or not. The scholarships are not political missionary
enterprises; a man is given an opportunity to study in a foreign
college in a foreign country where
the point of view differs entirely
from that to which he has been accustomed and the value of this
alone cannot be estimated in dollars and cents.

COACH LAMBORN DRILLS
BASKETEERS ON
TEAMWORK
No Individual Playing This Year.
Squad Unity to be Stressed. First
Game December 30.

The basketball team is rapidly
being whipped into first-class
shape under the able coaching of
Coach Lamborn. It was found impracticable to use the Armory this
week, so practice has been held
daily at Friends' School, where
due to the limited space only
about twenty men can work out.
Great attention is being paid to
the fundamentals of the game, a
large part of each afternoon being
devoted to the development of
passing, blocking and team work
Coach Lamborn is
in general.
laying the utmost stress on the
latter, for he believes that without
it no team can accomplish much.
This was well exemplified in the
team of last year, composed of five
individual stars who put up some
wonderful games, but who always
played as five men shooting for
the same basket, never as a team.
This year the long shots which
were so prominent last year are
to be done away with, and though
there are no men of the brilliancy
of Scheurich or Weinert, yet there
is ample material for a good team.
Under Coach Lamborn men such
as Capt. "Bill" Wood, Cashell,
Kennedy, Bauernschmidt, Owings,
Barrett, Jolson and Jefferson
can be moulded into a fast, unified team which should do very
well with the splendid schedule
Manager Reed has provided. The
first game will be played at the
Armory on December 30 with
Union. The rest of the schedule
is as follows:
January 7—Swarthmore.
January 14—Rutgers.
January 21—Open.
January 28—George Washington (away).
February 4—Washington and
Lee.

February 17—Princeton.

The Swimming Team commenced practice in earnest last
Wednesday afternoon in the B. A.
C. tank. Coach Henry was on
hand and put the men through
their customary paces, holding the
watch on some who have been
working out regularly for some
time. This early in the season it
is impossible to make any definite
predictions as to the men who are
slated to represent the University
during the year, but it seems that
the team should be as strong ag
formerly in all departments except
the "plunge for distance, as there
are but two candidates, neither of
whom are veterans, out for this
event.
In addition to Captain Rowland, one of the mainstays of the
team, the following men have
shown up exceptionally well:
Hall, Coady, Reins, Call, Johnston, Gould, Buhrer, Aguado,
Hambleton, Mellen and Keyes.
Manager Gould has completed
a well-balanced schedule, which,
however, calls for the majority of
meets taking place out of town,
leaving Hopkins rooters but two
chances to see their team in action. The schedule follows:
January 7—C. C. N. Y. at New
York.
January 8—Columbia at New
York.
January 15—Navy at Annapolis.
January 21—Swarthmore at
home.
February 18—Lehigh at South
Bethlehem.
February 25—Rutgers at home.

FRESHMAN-SOPHOMORE DEBATE SCHEDULED FOR
JANUARY 14
Question Same as Varsity Will Discuss
In Triangular Contest. Undergraduate Orchestra to
Furnish Music.

The Freshman-Sophomore debate will be held in the C. E. Hall
Friday night, January 14. The subject for debate will be on the same
general question as that which
will be discussed by the Varsity
team in the Triangular Debates
with North Carolina and Washington and Lee. The proposition
has been amended to read, "Resolved, That all immigration, save
of children, parents, or husband
or wife of people now resident in
the United States, be stopped for
a period of ten years." This reading of the proposition gives the op.
posing teams no room for • quibbling and presents a real bone of
contention.
The teams picked to represent
the., two classes are unusually
good. The Sophomores are able
to present intact the team which
was easily victorious in last year's
Freshman-Sophomore struggle. P.
C. Williams, A. P. Emmart and
Diamond will debate with Herman for alternate. For the Freshman Barnhart, Mount and Terlitzky will mount the stump, with
Eisenberg in reserve. All of these
men have had prep school experience and Mount was one of the
shining lights down in Montgomery County.
The committee on arrangements
consists of B. S. Cannon, '22; L.
B. Fenneman,'23, and Devers,'24.
The Undergraduate Orchestra
will furnish music.

THE NEWS LETTER'S
MAILBAG
A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, But Shoulder the Responsibility.
All letters intended for publication
must be concise.
No attention will be paid to anonymous letters, but- names signed as an
evidence of good faith will not be printed
if request is made that they be omitted.
The publication of a letter is not to be
taken as an indorsement of its views by
THE NEWS-LETTER, which invites the
freest discussion of matters of general
interest.

To Editor of The News-Letter:
Dear Sir—I believe this is an
Opportune time to bring up a topic
which is of especial interest to fellows from out of town who are attending Hopkins. I refer to the
short vacations which the University extends at Christmas and
Easter. I think I speak for many
others beside myself when I voice
dissatisfaction with the present
arrangement. I know there are
many. students who live far from
Baltimore who are unable to make
the trip home in so short a time
and who feel that the expense is
not warranted for so short a vacation. Other universities are giving two and one-half weeks for
Christmas recess, thus enabling
nearly all their students to enjoy
their Christmas around the family
hearth. I think it is a crying
shame that the University officials
do not give a little more consideration to the men who come from
the four corners of the country to
extend the name and prestige of
their loved Alma Mater.
The Easter recess extends from
Thursday to Thursday. Why
could this not be extended to the
following Monday? If Hopkins is
ever going to draw men outside
of Baltimore it has got to show
more consideration for them and
enable them to be with their families for a time more nearly approaching that extended by other
institutions. I am writing this
not so much in the spirit of criticism as of fair play. Hopkins is
in Baltimore, but not all for Baltimore.
ROBERT K. GUGGENHEIMER.

J. H. U. PRODUCES MANY
EMINENT MEN
Its Small Student-Body
Stands Supreme in Field of
Geology.

With

(From The Baltimore News, December 16.)
Hopkins, as a developer of
scientific students, has prided
itself primarily, not so much in
the quantity of its university influx as in the quality of its university output. Being a local institution, few Baltimoreans stop
to consider its position as compared with other,great American
universities, consequently, when
one undertakes to search out comparative statistics, it is often necessary to seek for sources of information beyond the borders of
Maryland.
Interesting material in this respect has been provided by
Charles Keyes, an eminent scien
tist of the present day, who, after
a canvass of the "starred" men
from 30 leading universities of the
country, found that while Hopkins
ranked thirtieth so far as attendance was concerned,. among a
thousand American men who have
become great during their genera
tion, and who have maintained
themselves in the advance thought
of the nation, Hopkins turned out
no less than 240. In other words,
one-fourth of the master-minsls of
American science have been produced by the Baltimore mainspring of scientific training.
It seems rather remarkable in
a way that classes carrying the
least attendance are often more
fruitful in the production of lead-

George Otis Shilth, head of the
United States Geological Survey
at Washington and a geologist of
national repute, is one of many
Hopkins men connected with the

In this particular field, however, not more than four or five

Many men taking up this study

show any material increase in
geological work. While the class •
of '23 is the largest at the University few Sophomores have been
able to enter the course as yet.
Dr. C. K. Swartz, head of the department, has advanced requirements as far as possible in order
to discourage the entrance of the
two lower divisions of classmen,
as facilities for handling large
numbers are very limited.
Yet conditions on the whole
have not varied greatly. While
admitting but a comparatively
small number each year, Hopkins
has continued to maintain its enviable record, and its production
of eminent men is a sufficient criterion of its success in this regard.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, DECEMBER 21, 1920

DRAMATIC CLUB TO START
WORK ON MAJOR PRODUCTION

• •• ••••• II
• • II •• II • II •

II •

that means
the best
in clothes

"Captain Jenks of the Horse Marine"
Chosen—Actors and Property
Men Wanted.

The Dramatic Club has definitely decided on the play to be
given for its big production and
will start rehearsals Tuesday, December 22. The Club has already
given several one-act plays in their
studio in the "Barn" which have
been very successful, and in selecting a play for its major production has gotten one which will
appeal to the Hopkins man.
After very careful consideration
on the part of the Club it has been
decided to present "Captain Jenks
of the Horse Marine," by Clyde
Fitch, a comedy in three acts. The
Club will again have the services
of Miss Clementine Walter as director. Miss Walter has coached
the Club in all its major productions since its foundation
three years ago and is largely responsible for the high standing
which it holds.
The Club makes, a special appeal for men who will take female
parts in the play and also for scenery painters and electricians. One
need have no experience in properties to try out for that end.
There are many openings for both
cast and business end which will
be filled by the men who show
themselves most capable and inter
ested.
In order to put this play on,
which will cost at least $1000, it
is imperative that the Club have
the backing of the entire studentbody—every man of it—and their
friends. The rehearsals and tryouts will begin on Tuesday, December 22, from 1 to 6 o'clock, in
the Club studio. Rehearsals will
be held during Christmas week
but will be called off the two weeks
preceding examinations.
